title: The rise and fall of the medieval Islamic Empire - Petra Sijpesteijn & Birte Kristiansen

options.label: B
options.text: The prophet Muhammad

options.label: C
options.text: The leader of the Quraysh tribe

options.label: D
options.text: The leader of the Umayyad Dynasty

options.label: B
options.text: The Abbasid family came to power and relocated the capital to Baghdad

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because the human body is made up of mostly bone, which is a good conductor.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the earthworms are trying to escape the vibrations, which they find uncomfortable.

options.text: Because the earthworms believe they are being pursued by a predator, such as a mole.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the earthworms think it is raining and want to avoid drowning.

title: The true cost of gold - Lyla Latif

multiple-choice.question: In 2020, Mali produced an estimated 71.2 tons of gold, but the country only saw $850 million from gold. What is the main reason behind this disparity?

options.text: Lack of infrastructure to mine and export gold

options.label: B
options.text: Low price of gold in the global market

options.label: C
options.text: Over-reliance on small-scale miners

options.label: D
options.text: Inefficient tax collection system

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: By negotiating contracts that exempt them from paying taxes for several years

options.text: By investing in the country's infrastructure

options.label: D

options.label: B

title: What’s the best country to live in?

options.label: D

title: The British Museum is full of stolen artifacts

multiple-choice.question: What is the British Museum, and what does it hold?

options.label: A
options.text: The British Museum is a natural history museum, and it holds over 8 million artifacts related to the natural world.

options.label: B
options.text: The British Museum is an art museum, and it holds over 8 million works of art from around the world.

options.label: C
options.text: The British Museum is a world history museum, and it holds over 8 million cultural and historical artifacts from all over the world.

options.label: D
options.text: The British Museum is a science museum, and it holds over 8 million scientific artifacts and exhibits.

multiple-choice.question: What is the problem with some of the artifacts in the British Museum?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too old and fragile to be displayed.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not well-documented or researched.

options.label: C
options.text: They have disputed ownership, with many countries and cultures claiming that they were taken without permission.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not relevant to modern society.

multiple-choice.question: What were the Benin bronzes, and where were they produced?

options.label: A
options.text: The Benin bronzes were a collection of ancient Greek sculptures, and they were produced in Athens.

options.label: B
options.text: The Benin bronzes were a collection of African art pieces, and they were produced in the kingdom of Benin in present-day Nigeria.

options.label: C
options.text: The Benin bronzes were a collection of Roman artifacts, and they were produced in Rome.

options.label: D
options.text: The Benin bronzes were a collection of Chinese art pieces, and they were produced in Beijing.

multiple-choice.question: Why did the British take the Benin bronzes, and what happened to the kingdom of Benin?

options.label: A
options.text: The British took the Benin bronzes because they were interested in learning about African art and culture, and the kingdom of Benin was not affected.

options.label: B
options.text: The British took the Benin bronzes as part of a punitive expedition, and the kingdom of Benin was conquered and destroyed.

options.label: C
options.text: The British took the Benin bronzes because they were valuable, and the kingdom of Benin was able to negotiate their return.

options.label: D
options.text: The British took the Benin bronzes by mistake, and the kingdom of Benin was not affected.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current status of the Benin bronzes, and what are the British Museum's plans for them?

options.label: A
options.text: The Benin bronzes have been returned to Nigeria, and the British Museum is working to rebuild its collection.

options.label: B
options.text: The Benin bronzes are still held by the British Museum, and the museum plans to return them to Nigeria in the near future.

options.label: C
options.text: The Benin bronzes are still held by the British Museum, and the museum has no plans to return them to Nigeria.

options.label: D
options.text: The Benin bronzes are on loan to other museums around the world, and the British Museum plans to sell them to the highest bidder.

title: Why can parrots talk? - Grace Smith-Vidaurre and Tim Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about parrots and a few other bird species compared to other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a highly developed sense of smell.

options.label: B
options.text: They are able to produce human speech.

options.label: C
options.text: They have exceptional night vision.

options.label: D
options.text: They can fly at extremely high speeds.

multiple-choice.question: Why do some parrot species, like the yellow-naped Amazon, have a high ability to mimic sounds, including the human voice?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a large brain-to-body mass ratio.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they have a need for sophisticated mimicry to communicate within their social groups.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they have a highly developed sense of hearing.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are known to be one of the most intelligent bird species.

options.label: B
options.text: Syrinx

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: They have a smaller brain-to-body mass ratio.

options.label: B
options.text: They have a single song system in their brains.

options.label: C
options.text: They have an additional circuit in their brains that allows for extra flexibility in learning vocalizations.

options.label: D
options.text: They have a less developed auditory cortex.

multiple-choice.question: What was notable about the African grey parrot named Alex?

options.label: A
options.text: He was able to mimic a wide range of sounds, including car alarms and animal noises.

options.label: B
options.text: He was able to learn and perform complex tricks.

options.label: C
options.text: He was the first non-human animal to pose an existential question.

options.label: D
